resources.string: Need some information or help getting started using the app? Read the guide.
What is the current cloud coverage?
Are you sure you want to stop the survey? All data will be lost!
Start the survey once ready in order to start collecting data.
Unable to find sighting, please try again.
Are you sure you want to delete this sighting?
What is the current wind speed?
Share any remarks about your survey
Thank you so much for your contribution towards cleaner oceans. Make sure you remember to upload your results!
Your survey is done! Continue to finalize.
There are currently no profiles, create a profile using the 'new profile' or plus botton.
Are you sure you want to delete this profile?
Failed to find profile, please restart the app and try again.
As a ‘debris spotter’ on a moving vessel, you are looking for debris that is floating at sea, and recording what you see in The Ocean Cleanup app.

Each survey takes 30 minutes and requires your full attention and sufficient battery of your device. Choose the side of the vessel- starboard or port side - that allows you to best see floating debris, given the available sunlight and wind conditions.

Your standing point must remain the same during the entire 30-minutes visual survey.

If this is your first visual survey using this app, make sure to take some time to have a look at our guide and settings. The settings tab gives you the option to choose between Metric and Imperial systems for the measurements you will have to estimate during the survey.

Note that even if you don't spot much or any debris, these data are just as useful and important as when you do.

Navigate to the ‘Surveys’ page of The Ocean Cleanup app. If it shows a bar with a 'no GPS found' error to the bottom of that page, click the bar to find ways to solve it. Once you have GPS, press ‘Start a new survey’.

The app will then give you the opportunity to either select your existing profile or create a new one. Provide your full name and email, the boat name, and platform height, which is an estimate of the distance between your eyes and the mean water line. Your email address is only used in case there are any questions about your survey.

Next, it will ask you the current wind speed (if there's no anemometer, estimate it) and cloud coverage (estimate it).

You are now ready to get the 30 minutes ocean watch started!

You are now in a screen with a countdown timer that tells you how much time you have left before the 30 minutes survey is over. The app will keep track of your location so that we know which area was surveyed and what your speed was.

You should focus your attention on looking for debris floating within a 90-degree arc encompassing the area ahead of the ship and one side of the vessel.

You should be searching for debris in closeby waters - 0 - 10 meters from the boat - but debris sighted at any distance can be recorded. Please ignore items smaller than 1 cm (half an inch, or roughly the width of a pinky nail).

When you spot a debris item, press ‘New Sighting’ to log the debris details.

Please take the time you need to estimate and enter the item's details. You don't need to be looking out for other debris while you log the details.
What's the true wind speed right now? Check your anemometer (windmeter) if available. Otherwise estimate it yourself or ask your captain.\n\nWind speed affects the visibility of debris.
Are there clouds? How much of the sky do they approximately cover? This affects the visibility of debris.
Are you seeing a group of similar items? You can report them at once. You can add remarks to group sighting as well.
What does this item appear to consist of? For a group of items, what do most appear to be made of?

Is it one of these items, per chance? Select your best guess of what the item you're seeing is. You can use "other" if it is a recognizable item that is not listed, or "no clue" if it is a more or less intact item that you do not recognise.

How long is the object, or most objects in the group? Please ignore items smaller than 1 cm (half an inch, or roughly the width of a pinky nail). Smaller items shouldn't be recorded as these are measured with trawls with nets instead.
How far is it from the vessel right now? Remember to focus your attention on the first 0-10 meters (0-33 feet) from you.

You're almost finished. Well done! Please use this box to tell us about things like:

- Anything special that happened during the survey. Did you spot dolphins? Fish? Spilled oil?
- If a second spotter helped you
- Things that may affect the quality of the survey, e.g. rain, bad visibility or distractions
- Any feedback you have to improve the app

Also don't forget to switch on 'Save survey on as test' if this was a test survey.

And then you're ready to finalize it! Thanks so much!

What stands out about the group of items you see? Use this box to tell us anything we should know about what you're seeing - e.g. an estimate of the total amount or a guess of the origin of the group of items.

Your survey data is most helpful when GPS data from your device is automatically included. Everywhere on earth, your device can detect your location thanks to satellites. If you have no signal, please try these things to fix it:

- Make sure there's nothing above your head (e.g. roof, solar panels...) that may interfere with the signals.
- Make sure this app has permission to access your location in the settings on your device.
- Make sure your device is unlocked and flight mode is disabled.
- Open Google Maps or another maps app and let it determine your location. (It doesn't need internet for this so don't worry if no map shows.)
- If none of the above helps, reboot your device by turning it off and on again and if necessary, repeat the above steps once.

Phew! This should almost always help your device find the GPS location.

Do none of these help? Is it still not working? You can also add the coordinates manually, at the start and again at the end of your survey. Note that these must be in decimals, not in minutes. Please do try the above steps first as your data will be less useful if the coordinates of every sighting can not be logged.

When the 30 minutes ocean watch is over, your device will vibrate to let you know that the survey is over.

You wil then have the opportunity to write down any remarks you may have, such as app improvement suggestions and reports of unusual sightings (e.g. marine life, weather condition changes), as well as whether someone helped you. This is also where you can let us know if this was a test survey rather than real data.

Once you're back on land, don't forget to upload your data.
Before you start a new survey, it is important that you have filled in your personal and vessel details. This enables us to link the survey data to the right vessel and team.
How to set up your spotter profile

To set up your spotter profile, go to the profiles page using the menu or simply press 'start survey'. On the profiles page you will be able to create a new profile with the 'new profile' or plus button. Provide your full name and email, the boat name, and platform height, which is an estimate of the height of your eyes from the mean water line. Your email address is only used in case there are any questions about your survey.

Is the answer to your question not available in this guide? Do you experience a problem with the use of the app or when conducting a survey? Please don't hesitate to let us know. You may include feedback in your Remarks at the end of your next survey, or email your feedback to app@theoceancleanup.com
"When I orbited the Earth in a spaceship, I saw for the first time how beautiful our planet is. Mankind, let us preserve and increase this beauty and not destroy it."
YURI A. GAGARIN, first man in space.

Plastic pollution has become a major hazard to marine life and is also leading to aesthetic degradation, economic losses, and impacts on human health. The Ocean Cleanup aims to mitigate ocean plastic pollution by starting effective at-sea cleanup operations. The Ocean Cleanup’s goal is to fuel the world’s fight against oceanic plastic pollution, by initiating the largest cleanup in history.

By conducting visual surveys the Ocean Cleanup will be able to estimate the amounts and types of objects floating in our oceans. This knowledge is crucial to develop technologies to clean it up. Your help is greatly appreciated!

Julia Reisser (Ocean Research)
Harrie Pieters (App Developer, UI and UX)
Bart Sturm (UX, Server and Testing)
The Smiths (Android development)
Explainer Heroes (Videos)
Eva Seignette (Testing) 
Daniel Baker (Icons)
